title: How to control industrial pollution - Quora

response.answer_text: You drive your car. Think of pollution from its emissions. Have you ever thought why does the tyre wears down after 70,000–80,000 kilometers drive? Where does the rubber go? You cook food, and switch on the exhaust or electric chimney. All fumes go outside. Where do these go? You take a bath and use soap, shampoo, conditioner etc. After the bath, you apply hair oil or gel. Next day, you take a bath again. You need to use hair oil again. Why? Where does it go? Unfortunately, most people think it is only the industry that pollute. A few, however, think though other sources exist, yet, industry is the biggest source of pollution. I recall, when I was a small kid (maybe 10–12 yrs old), my mother asked me sometimes to bring a pack of detergent- 500 gm pack. In a family of five, a pack served for a month or more. Now, my son stays in other city, and me and my wife stay together. We use washing machine for washing clothes, and maid maybe loves the detergent. The consumption now is to the tune of 5 kg per month. That too after repeatedly asking my wife to reduce it. She can do nothing but to remind the maid every second day to use less detergent, of course with an inherent fear to get branded as ‘miser’! There are several government agencies to control industrial pollution. The check and control industries. Maybe one or two mills are really polluting, but believe me, most of them (at least 90–95%) are following the law. The most unfortunate is that no government agency is allowed to check you at your homes. How much soap, shampoo, conditioner you are using while taking a bath, how much hair oil you apply, how much detergent you use for washing your clothes. Behind the closed doors of bathrooms, we pollute a lot, and blame our industries more and more. My request is to read the matter written again twice, and think- “What is your personal contribution to pollution prevention?”

In United State, industries are the single largest source of air pollution. People who think they cannot control the industrial pollution are wrong. If they take individual or collective action to reduce it, then they will certainly do it. Do adopt the below mentioned steps for the said purpose:- - You must read labels and reject the products which are using questionable ingredients such as solvents, acids and heavy metals find their way into or environment through storm drains or landfills. When no one bought these products, then industries will no longer manufactures them. - Reject the companies who are discouraging in recycling of their products. Many of the products are coming with unnecessary packaging and they are using plastics that has toxic ingredients.. Prefer the companies that use a minimum of packaging. - Proper investigation should be done in relation to the location of the company's plants. If its manufacturing plant is located in some poor country it means the company is trying to avoid the stringent U.S. environmental regulations to save money and cut labor costs. It will be better to avoid the products that company , as they are contributing to pollution. - Read reports from environmental groups such as the Sierra Club and make yourself aware of some of the worst polluters, especially local ones. Contact your local Environmental Protection Agency branch, which you can locate on the EPA's website, or your state health department, and demand enforcement of the law. - If need be call or write your congressional representative or senator and request them to take action regarding industrial polluting activities that fall outside the law. It will be better if you will get some like-minded people to sign a petition in support of your request. - It will be also good to support the companies that promote "green" methods of production and products. As they make more money and gain a greater market share, their polluting competitors will pay attention and be encouraged to change their ways. -Visit industries and check whether they are using air pollution control structures. If no , then give them proper time. If still they do not follow the norms, bring the fact before the concerned department, who will themselves take action against them.

Since I can’t tell what country you are in, the answer is specific to the country in question and the laws which are available. In the U.S. we created the Clean Air Act in 1965, but it didn’t have a lot of impact until the 1972 revisions. You can read the entire history on Wikipedia. And it depends on the pollution in question. I can’t give you a simple concrete answer without knowing a lot more. Perhaps this will help: Identify the problem you are trying to solve - specific sources, and specific chemicals or pollutants. Identify the harm being done, in as clear terms as you can.Learn what your legal options are. If you have none, or they are inadequate, find out who has done a good job of addressing the sort of problem you face in another country or another part of your country.Learn as much as you can about the pollutant and the industry you are dealing with.Identify the decisionmakers. This can include the corporate management, the parent company if one exists, local and higher political officials, and if you have good laws, the regulators.Figure out the best strategy to approach the easiest pathway to the solution you want. ALWAYS know as much as you can possibly know about the solution you want. Most of the time people ask for solutions, but don’t know what they are asking for, so the person who is being asked still doesn’t know what to do. It’s possible to get a response by pointing at a smokestack or drainpipe, but it is a lot more likely to work if you know what they are doing, what their options are, and sometimes good activists even know what the options cost.Enlist as many people as you can who care about the same thing, and have a means of getting them all to chime in if there is a focus for the conversation, including hearings, obstinate decisionmakers who need to know there is public support or pressure, and think about identifying supportive newspersons.Try to keep civil. A lot of times people get angry before they start a conversation. It’s very hard for people responsible for many jobs and a lot of production to respond to a challenge to their operation when the people raising the problem start off angry. Corporations are often willing to be good citizens if they don’t feel like they have already lost public support no matter what they do.If that doesn’t work, sue the bastards.That last one was for fun. Sometimes it is necessary. But most often, the hardest part is identifying the problem and solution clearly enough that people who have authority understand and agree with the solution you propose.Last, but not least, consider alternatives, including boycotting products, helping the company move to a less polluting process or technology, and forcing or supporting them to move away from the community which is being affected.Good luck. It’s good work!

A15 Hello!! Thanks for asking As you know industries are one of the most important factors of the growth of our country as well as one of the biggest contributor to the pollution. The industries pollute the environment in various ways. Now it is the need of hour for industries to step-up and take responsibility for the environment. I'll list some of the ways they can do so Air pollution: modifying their machinery to pollute less, using less polluting fuels, using electrostatic precipitators (Electrostatic precipitator - Wikipedia), filtering the waste air properly, using less polluting raw materials, shifting the industries away from cities etc.Water pollution: proper treatment of waste water, disposing off chemicals with proper treatment, not cooling the equipments in water bodies with life, not disposing industrial waste in water, etc.Soil pollution: again proper treatment of the wastes, avoiding land fillings, not disposing harmful chemicals or the waste or leftover products in the land, etc.Sound pollution: proper machinery, repairing oor replacement of damaged one, using sound barriers, establishing the industries in outskirts of the major cities, etc.There are no easy ways to do this. But the proper and stricter implementation of laws and rules made to keep pollution in check is the most important thing. Self awareness and realisation is also necessary. Pardon me for any mistakes.
